data.Article: The Garbham Manganese Occurrence is in Andhra Pradesh, India.Ore mineralization has been found at this location, however the precise grade, tonnage, and extent of the mineralization are not known. There has been no production and little to no activity other than routine claim maintenance since the mineral discovery. The ore mined is composed of braunite, pyrolusite and bixbyite with waste material consisting primarily of garnet, goethite and quartz. The ore is found in stratiform deposits 5 meters (16 feet) thick. The host rock in this area is quartzite from the Neoproterozoic era 1.00 to 0.54 billion years ago.

Can be approached by both rail and roadways. Railway line is linked with the Tinsukia junction. 29 Km long and 4.6 Km wide area. Coal bearing rocks belongs to the Tikak Parbat and Bargolai Formation.

The coalfield is connected by a 12 Km road with Namrup railway station. The coalfield can also be approached from Sivsagar via Sonari and from Dibrugarh via Naharkatia and Duliajan. Area of 40 km. long and 0.50 km. Wide. Four distinct geological horizons belonging to Tikak Parbat Formation exist in this area where thicker seams of coal occur towards the bottom. About ten coal seams of various thickene sses ranging from 0.50m to 21m are located in the lowermost horizon.
5 Km SW of Bhadoi Panch Ali of Tinsukia district linked with Duliajan-Digboi road. Coal occurs intermittently along the strike length of 7 Km.
40 Km northwest of Diphu and 110 Km southeast of Nagaon on NH-36 Two coal seams separated by carbonaceous shale. Average thickness of coal seam: 2.35m Area: 0.2 sq. Km..
8 Km NW of Dilai on ManjaSarihajan road. 1.8 m thick coal seam occurs within the Basal Sandstone Formation at Koliajan Nala covering an area of about 0.4 sq.km

Near Timang Basti and can be approached from Umrongsho through a metalled road. The coal occurs in association with Barail Sandstone Formation of Jaintia Group of rocks covering an area of 2.5 sq.Km. Three coal seams associated with Basal Sandstone are exposed intermittently along both the banks of Kopili river. The thickness of coal seams varies from 0.30 m to 1.5 m.

The deposit can be approached by Dayanamukh – Dihangi road and situated at 35 km. south of Lanka railway station and 93 km. away from the district HQ Haflong. Two nos. of coal seams separated by a thin band of carbonaceous shale are exposed within Kopili Formation at Phanglangsho nala over an area of about 1.5 sq. Km. The thickness of coal seams varies from 0.50 to 1.00 m.

The deposit is located near Umrangsho and can be approached by 6 km. long forest road from Lanka – Garampani Road. A small band of upper Eocene coal occurs within Kopili Formation of Jaintia Group of rocks. The thickness of coal seams varies from 0.20 m to 0.85m.
Connected by metalled road about 19 Km from Bokajan railway station. Dillai Parbat Deposit is divided into two blocks, viz., East block and North block.
On NH 36. 122 Km from Nagaon and 37 Km from Diphu railway station. Small bands of cement grade limestone occur.
25 Km from Dimapur railway station. Small to medium bands of limestone occur.
Near 18 Km post of Garampani -Lanka road. Two bands of limestone 30m and 50m thickness intervened by shale band.
In Umrongsho. 6 Km from Umrongsho and 12 Km from Lanka Covers a total area of 1.07 sq.Km. where the total thickness of limestone is 80 m.
Near Umrongsho-Lanka road in between 22 Km post and 23 km post. Occupies an area of about 6.5 sq. Km.
Located on the north bank of river Brahmaputra and is about 2 km away from Salkocha Inspection Bunglow on NH 31. Three bands are found with thicknesses of 49.85 m, 16m, and 53 m.
15 km awa7 from agia along NH - 37 Occurs mainly on the hilltop forming a prominent ridge in the area. Two bands are found with a thickness of 10 m and 20 m respectively.
6 km west of Pancharatna. Exposed legally at western side of the hill. Two bands are found with a thickness ranging from 10 m to 16 m.

3 km southeast of Chapanala, 12 km from Samuguri railway station and 25 km from Nagaon town via NH – 37.Covers an area of 2.9 Sq.km. However , detailed investigation of the deposit covered an area of 0.552 sq. km.

7.5 Km west of Safapani, Safapani is 24 Km from Bokajan railway station. Two good deposits at 500 m apart. Both slacking & non-slacking varieties present. Block-I: area = 0.4 sq. Km. Block-II: area = 0.043 sq. Km.
Well connected by metal road to NH 36. Covers 0.25 Sq.Km.
8 Km from NH-39 near Silonijan. Covers an area of 5 sq. Km. Thickness ranges from 3– 6 m.
Situated near Dokmoka beside NH 36 and 92 Km away from Diphu. Pink Granite. Massive, hard and fractured in nature.
Located beside NH 36 60 Km. away from Diphu. Pink Granite. Massive, hard and fractured in nature.
14 km. away from Dokomoka along NH 36. Light colourd, coarse to medium grained, massive and gray granite.
The area is connected by an all weather road stretching west of proper Silonijan along NH 39. Massive, dark pink, coarse and fractured with hypidiomorphic texture and located is an isolated pocket.

The area is connected by a fair weather road of 3 km stretching from Kathiatoli – salna road and situated at a distance of 20 km from Nagaon and about 180 km from the district H.Q. Diphu. Black in colour, hard, massive, fine grained and well fractured.
Nearby Boko and about 55 km west of Guwahati along NH 37. Light Pink. Hard and massive in nature.
Situated at a distance of 50 km west of Guwahati along NH 37.Pink Granite. Hard and massive in nature
8 km south of Agia. Greenish black. Hard and massive in nature.
3 km away from Balbola an about 17 km from Goalpara town. Greenish black Hard, massive granite.
14 km SW of Goalpara and 6 km away from Pancharatna Black Granite. Hard, massive granite.
16 Km southwest of Goalpara and 8 km Away from Pancharatna Black Granite. Hard, massive granite.

The Shumahal Copper Mine is in Jammu And Kashmir, India. The Shumahal Copper Mine was closed at the time of data entry with no known plans to re-open.

The Doga Copper Prospect is in Jammu And Kashmir, India. Preliminary development has taken place such as surface trenching, adits, shafts, drill holes, geophysics, geochemistry, or geological mapping. Enough data has been gathered to estimate grade and tonnage. Information from 1978 described the ore body as having an unknown shape and extends 9.00 meters (29.53 feet) long and 0.60 meters (1.97 feet) wide.
